awd_titl_txt: Random Matrix Theory for Homogenization of Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
1715680
Golden

     Composite materials are highly valued in engineering and manufacturing for their unique physical and chemical properties that are superior to those of conventional products.  Science and industry are continually searching for composites that are stronger, lighter, and less expensive than their traditional counterparts.  These structured media -- or metamaterials -- may exhibit increased electrical conductivity, enhanced thermal or acoustic insulation properties, more reliable durability, or even seemingly unattainable properties such as invisibility.  Specific examples include lighter wings and fuselage materials for aircraft, body armor for the military, artificial joints used in orthopedic surgery, and professional sporting equipment.  Composites also appear throughout the natural world -- in human and animal bodies, and in most components found within and on the surface of the Earth.  Examples include bone, lungs, porous rocks containing oil and gas, agricultural soils, and sea ice.  The mathematical theory of homogenization for composite materials has been developed to explain observed effective properties of existing composites, which can then be used to predict and discover new composites with less need for costly experimentation.  Recently the investigators discovered an unexpected mathematical parallel between homogenization for composites and the Anderson theory of the metal-insulator transition, for which Anderson shared the Nobel prize.  In this project the investigators develop new methods for studying composites based on this parallel, bringing the powerful ideas of the Anderson transition to bear on a broad range of problems in the theory of composites.  Graduate and undergraduate students participate in the work of the project.

     In this project the spectral theory of homogenization for transport in composite media is investigated through the lens of random matrix theory.  A powerful approach to homogenization problems is the analytic continuation method, which encodes information about the microstructure of the composite through the spectral measure of a self-adjoint random operator governing classical transport in the medium.  Random matrix theory naturally arises by considering finite discrete models of composites, which allows the spectral measure, and thus the macroscopic behavior of the composite, to be computed in terms of the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of the random matrices.  Surprisingly, as a percolation threshold is approached, these eigenvalues and eigenvectors display strikingly similar behavior to what is observed in Anderson transitions in condensed matter, optics, acoustics, and water waves.  This unexpected connection enables the investigators to develop new methods of analysis and computation for homogenization of two-phase composites and related systems such as polycrystals and advection-diffusion processes.  Moreover, their approach ties together previously unrelated fields of random matrix theory and homogenization, opening up new avenues for investigation and application.  Graduate and undergraduate students participate in the work of the project.

por.por_cntn:
Composite materials are manufactured or arise naturally when two or more constituent media are combined to make a new material with effective or homogenized properties that are different or perhaps more desirable than the properties of the constituents. They are ubiquitous in the physical and biological sciences, and are the foundational cornerstones of a broad range of industrial and medical applications. Increasingly, composites allow engineers to design and build new products based on lighter, stronger, more durable, or more efficient materials than were previously available. 

One of the fundamental challenges of working with composite materials is how to determine their bulk properties like electrical or thermal conductivity from the properties of the constituents and the mixture geometry, or designing geometries that achieve specific, desired behavior. The problem of finding the effective transport properties of composites has a long and storied history. Maxwell and Einstein were some of the first scientists to work on these problems, and there were many major advances in the latter part of the 20th century in the physics, mathematics and engineering communities.

In this project we discovered and built upon unexpected parallels between the theory of bulk transport in two phase composites and the solid state physics of periodic and amorphous materials at the atomic scale. These parallels helped enable us to introduce a new class of tunable materials, which we call twisted bilayer composites. They have exotic electrical, magnetic, optical, diffusive, and thermal properties, and their mixture geometries are based on Moire interference patterns produced by rotating one square lattice relative to another. The mixtures can be tuned to have periodic or quasiperiodic microstructure, and are very closely related to twisted bilayer graphene, where two sheets of carbon atoms, located at the vertices of hexagonal lattices, are rotated relative to each other. These important materials, where quantum effects drive the system, become superconducting at a magic twist angle. We observe in our twisted bilayer composites many unusual but novel and potentially very useful properties which are driven geometrically over almost any relevant range of scales, from nanometers to tens of meters or larger!

Other results we obtained enable our mathematical framework to be extended to polycrystalline materials like metals, rocks, sea ice, and land ice, and advection diffusion systems like convection enhanced thermal transport through sea ice. We advanced the underlying mathematics by investigating idealized discrete models of composites, which involves graph theory, significant computation, and unexpected connections to data science. The project provided many opportunities for research and training of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, as well as outreach to the public through media interest in our findings, such as an extensive article in Popular Mechanics on our twisted bilayer composites.
